isis.stitle: 530 and DT-466/408 Diesel Engine Service (1994) - NOZZLES - NOZZLES - RETESTING AND ADJUSTING CLEAN NOZZLE ASSEMBLIES

svcproc.title: RETESTING AND ADJUSTING CLEAN NOZZLE ASSEMBLIES

caution.para: Keep hands away from the nozzle discharge. Fluid discharging from the nozzle under high pressure can penetrate the skin and cause infection. Medical attention should be provided immediately in the event of skin penetration.

step1.para:
Using VISCOR 1487C (SAE J967 Standard) calibration fluid and a standard hand test pump ZTSE4045A, equipped with a pressure gauge having a capacity of at least 27,600 kPa (4000 psi), proceed as follows: (Refer to Figure 12.14
).

step2.para: Attach the nozzle tube assembly ZTSE4045 to the nozzle hand test pump.
Attach the 90° adapter ZTSE4045 to the nozzle tube.
Attach nozzle and holder assembly loosely to the test pump. Pump the handle several times to flush out the fittings; then tighten.

step1.para: Test each nozzle for opening pressure as follows:

OPENING PRESSURE TEST: Pump the test pump handle a few strokes to clear the air from the nozzle and then raise the pressure steadily. Observe the gauge pressure at which the valve opens. Refer to the Nozzle Test Chart in this section for the specified opening pressure. If the pressure is incorrect, adjust by selecting a different size spacer.

note.para: A 0.001 inch (0.025 mm) change in the spacer will result in a 55 psi (379 kPa) change in pressure.

step1.para: Test each nozzle for seat leakage as follows:

SEAT LEAKAGE TEST: Wipe the nozzle tip dry. Bring the pressure up slowly to 500 psi (3447 kPa) below the nozzle opening pressure and maintain this pressure for 5 seconds. If fluid leaks or drips from the nozzle or a visible drop forms, the nozzle is leaking (slight moistening of the nozzle tip is permissible). Recondition or replace a leaking nozzle.

note.para: Do not wipe the tip with the fingers as this will tend to draw the fuel present in the sac hole through the orifices and falsely indicate a leak resulting in the rejection of a good valve.

step1.para: Leakage at the seat may be caused by dirt or foreign material, carbon or gum deposits at the seat area or excessive wear of the seat. If the seat is worn, replace the nozzle body and nozzle valve.

note.para: Never lap the valve-to-body seat. This will only widen the seat area and prevent sealing.

step1.para: Test each nozzle for spray pattern as follows:
SPRAY PATTERN TEST: Close pressure gauge valve. Operate test pump at a moderate rate and observe the spray pattern.

step2.para: All of the fluid should be atomized and each hole should spray approximately the same amount of fuel.
The spray patterns for all holes should be uniform.

note.para: Upon operating the test pump you will note a distinct and relatively regular nozzle chatter. A sharp pitched sound is not mandatory and an occasional skip or variation in sound may occur. In addition, chatter may vary from nozzle to nozzle. Lack of chatter is not a cause for rejection of a nozzle.

step1.para: STEM LEAKAGE: Bring the pressure on the nozzle to 1500 psi (10342 kPa). If there is any leakage from the return, collect it. To conserve time, nozzle may be in inverted position. The maximum allowable leakage is 1.0 cc in one minute at this pressure.

Excessive leakage at this point can be caused by scratches or poor sealing at the flat lapped surfaces of the nozzle body, intermediate plate or valve body. If this possibility has been already eliminated, there is excessive clearance between the valve stem and body. This condition necessitates replacement of the nozzle.
After nozzles meet testing standards and adjustments are made, you may install nozzle assemblies.
